description: Verona was an ancient settlement that became a Roman colonia in 89 BC and a municipium in 49 BC.
The capital of the Roman Republic and Empire.
A city of northern Adriatic Italy that served as the capital of the Western Roman Empire from A.D. 402 until 476.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 84 E3 Sarmatia
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 22 E5 Marcianopolis
An Iberian site in contact with Greek and Phoenician merchants that became a major Roman center from the third century BC onward.
A Celtic settlement and crossroads, later a Western Roman capital. Now modern Milan, Italy.
The region of ancient Macedonia in the Balkan peninsula. The boundaries of the region have shifted significantly over time, and remain controversial.
An ancient settlement of Asia Minor on the south coast of the Black Sea. Modern Trabzon in Turkey.
A region of northeastern Anatolia consisting of the southeastern coast of the Black Sea and the surrounding inland region.
Chalcedon was an ancient maritime city of Bithynia.
Nicomedia was founded in 712/11 BC as a Megarian colony named Astacus and was rebuilt by Nicomedes I of Bithynia in 264 BC. The city was an important administrative center of the Roman Empire.

Settlement at Prusa began as a site called Cius that came under the control of the king of Bithynia in 202 BC. The city was renamed Prusias and was eventually willed to the Roman Empire in 74 BC by Nicomedes IV, the last King of Bithynia.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 22 F4 Cius
An ancient city of Mysia in Anatolia.
Heraclea was an ancient city of Magna Graecia.
The ancient, fortified port settlement (and deme) of ancient Athens.
A major Greek city-state and the principal city of Attika. Modern Athens in Greece.
The ancient city of Thebes in Boeotia (modern Greece).
Argos was a city of ancient Greece that reached its cultural highpoint under Pheidon in the seventh century BC.
The ancient Greek and Roman city of Corinth, located in the Peloponnese, Greece. Also known today as Archaia Korinthos and not to be confused with the nearby modern town.
Sparta was a prominent city-state (polis) of ancient Greece.
An ancient region that included northwest parts of modern Greece and the southern tip of modern Albania.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 22 E6 Anchialus

Carrhae is a major settlement of Upper Mesopotamia from the Bronze Age onward. The earliest mentions of the site are found in the Ebla tablets (ca. 2300 B.C.). Notably the location of the Battle of Carrhae between the Roman Republic and Parthian Empire in 53 B.C., which proved to be a devastating defeat for the Romans. Modern-day Ḥarrān, Turkey.

An ancient region, stretching along the southern coast of Asia Minor as far north as the Taurus mountains and westward from the Amanus mountains to the river Melas or, according to some ancient commentators, all the way to the coastal city of Korakesion (modern Alanya in Turkey)
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 55 F4 Chalcis

An ancient oasis and trading city with monumental remains, located in modern Syria. Under Zenobia, Palmyra was the capital of the breakaway Palmyrene Empire, leading to Aurelian's razing of the city. Inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1980.
Nemetacum was the principal center of the Atrebates.
Illyricum was a Roman province that existed from 167 BC until AD 10.
An ancient Greek region on the northern coast of the Peloponnese.

Sicily is the largest island in the Mediterranean Sea and has been the site of human habitation since ca. 8,000 BC. In historical terms Sicily has seen important settlement activity connected to numerous culture groups - Punic, Carthaginian, Greek, Roman, Vandalic, Ostrogothic, Byzantine, Arabic, and Norman.
A Roman province founded under Trajan shortly after 22 March 106 CE. It included the territory to the east of the Jordan river and the Sinai peninsula to the Red Sea.
An ancient place, cited: BAtlas 5 D2 India
